characters: INT. LANDMARK BUILDING, DANCE LOFT, NEW YORK, NIGHT
WITHIN A FILM, OF THE ROAD HE'S TAKEN...
THERE'S SUDDENLY AN EXPLOSION OF FIREWORKS.
INT. A ROOM, WHORE HOUSE, FRENCH QUARTER
INT. PARLOR, WHORE HOUSE, THE QUARTER
AND WE WILL SEE JUST WHAT HE IS DESCRIBING...
INT. THE ROOM, WHORE HOUSE, FRENCH QUARTER
INT. A CLUB, THE FRENCH QUARTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we see we're in a hospital room with layers of white enamel paint trying without success to hide the years... An old WOMAN, past 80, withered, still regal with a green turban around her bald head is propped by pillows, her blue eyes looking out at us from her bed... She's connected to an intravenous for sustenance and a morphine drip... Her name, is DAISY FULLER. She speaks with a Southern lilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it wasn't for hurricanes we wouldn't have a hurricane season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've forgotten what the weather can be like here. I've lived with four seasons so many years now. We see a young Black Woman, a "caregiver," DOROTHY BAKER, in a corner, thumbing a magazine, with one eye at the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw on the news they're predicting trouble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1928 they stacked people like firewood to close a hole in a levee. But Daisy has other things on her mind... murmuring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all runs together... like a fingerpainting... I feel like I'm on a boat, drifting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I do anything for you, Mother? Make anything easier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. There is nothing to do, Caroline. This is what it is... I'm finding it harder to keep my eyes open... my mouth all filled with cotton... And agitated, feeling confined, she scratches at her nightgown as if it were sticking to her... she starts to it off... Dorothy gets up and straightens it for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, there, Miss Daisy... you'll scratch yourself to ribbons... (to Caroline)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's their way of letting go... (the finality)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...prob'ly today. Caroline is well aware of it, but the words, her admonition of death being so close at hand, makes everything even more present...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want more medication, Mother? The doctor said you can have all you want. Daisy is quiet, looking into the distance. Caroline, seeking closure, sits on the bed with her and starts to cry. Daisy puts her thin arms around her daughter, comforting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend told me she never had a chance to say goodbye to her mother. (grateful to have the chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to thank you, Mother, for bringing me into this world. For raising me so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you how much you've meant to me. I'm going to miss you so much... They hold each other for some time... They separate... And there's an awkwardness they have nothing left to talk about... nothing left to say to each other... a hole in their relationship... Caroline fills it with the eternal question...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curious.   What comes next... She winces at some physical pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain's coming more steadily... Her breathing will falter soon... No need for her to suffer.. She raises the morphine level... Daisy closes her eyes... drifting with the morphine... and a thought, a dream, a sound, crosses her mind... and she says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They built that train station in 1918. Your father was there the day it opened... He said a tuba band was playing...Oom-pah-pah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see a TUBA BAND is playing while a ribbon cutting ceremony is taking place across the steps of the new TRAIN STATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oom-pah-pah, oom-pah-pah...The finest clockmaker in all of the South built that clock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an old French Quarter storefront with an endless array of clocks and watches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name was Mr. Gateau. Mr. Cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slightest of smiles crosses Daisy's lips... saying to herself again... "Mr. Cake..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a diminutive man in a frock coat with small, delicate hands, "Mr. Cake," working in his downstairs workshop. More than a few clocks stroke midnight, a handsome Creole Woman comes into the workshop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was married to a Creole of Evangeline Parish and they had a son. Taking his arm, she helps him up to show him to his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I mention, Mr. Gateau was from birth, absolutely blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The clockmaker his fine hands blindly working...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when their son came of age, like boys will do, he joined the army. They saw him off at the old train station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old wooden barn of a building. Their son, hugging his parents, getting on a flatbed train crowded with other soldiers, pulling away... Mr. Gateau, blindly waving his hat goodbye to his son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh how he worked, for months he did nothing but work on the clock for the great train station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of clocks constant ticking. Mr. Gateau at work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day a letter came... Blanche comes into the workshop... a letter in her hand... She reads to her blind husband...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I am sorry to inform you that your son was killed fighting for his country, at the battle of the Marne. In the death of Sgt. Martin Gateau I lose one of my most trusted men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I informed members of our company he had fallen, on every face could be seen the mark of sorrow... ...we were in hope the Lord would spare him to return home together... Alas this was not to be. I send along his pants, shirt, cavalry pin, kerchief, and haircomb."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gateau, done for the night, went up to his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gateau, blindly feeling his way up the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And their son came home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see "Mr. Cake" in his familiar hat, his wife holding his arm, standing among the rows of coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They buried him where the Gateau family had been buried for a hundred and seven years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old New Orleans cemetery, vines crawling the sepulchers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cake went back to work on his clock... laboring to finish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gateau blindly setting the last spring, closing up the clock back... finished at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a morning to remember... Papa said there were people everywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see a large throng gathered to watch the unveiling of the clock. Politicians, citizens, and pickpockets alike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Teddy Roosevelt had come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see the distinctive figure of Theodore Roosevelt, in overcoat and hat, the war heavy on his shoulders. We watch Mr. Cake, with the aid of an assistant, climbing the scaffolding to his clock covered by a velvet drape... He stands for a moment... and with a simple tug, releases the purple swath... People gasp at the magnificent clock... "Mr. Cake" winds the clock, which chimes a glorious chime... Pushed by an angel, the second-hand begins its eternal journey...going around... Everyone cheers... until they realize the clock is going the wrong way... traveling backwards in time... A man shouts, "It's running backwards!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made it this way... so that perhaps, the boys who were lost in the war might stand and go home again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see just that... bullets leaving mens' wounds sailing back into the rifles from whence they came... limbs, whole again... cannon balls rocketing backwards into the cannons' breech... Fallen come to their feet, to live and breathe again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... home to farm, to work, have children, to live long, full lives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy Roosevelt, bereft, removes his hat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, my own son might come home again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see his own son, Martin, once again full of life hopping backward off the train to land where his journey started... back in the arms of his loving parents...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I offended anybody. I hope you enjoy my clock. And his wife holding his arm, he makes his way across the terminal and exits... The crowd is motionless. They look to Teddy Roosevelt for guidance... but he simply puts his hat on, and with his guardians, is gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Cake was never seen again. Some say he died of a broken heart. Some say he went to sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gateau, blindly rowing... away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just rowed...rowed...away... The wind loudly rattles the window...they turn to look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I make myself a call? I've got somebody watching my little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please go call... It's quiet, Caroline sitting on the bed with her dying mother... with the wind knocking at the window... After some moments:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I haven't disappointed you, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh honey, you could never disappoint me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wished I had more to show for myself. I know you would have liked to have had grandchildren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life hasn't been all that... normal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if to say the pieces haven't all fit... trying to articulate it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm either a step ahead... or a step behind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's normal?     A hat full of sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going on) I need my brown suitcase... The envelope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An envelope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline doing what she's asked goes over to one of the suitcases by the bed... She opens it... and among the clothes and the keepsakes, there is indeed an old envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to read it a hundred different times... but I couldn't bring myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy closes her eyes... Caroline takes out a sheath of papers... It's a journal of some kind written in longhand... Pages have come undone... scraps of paper, even some napkins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs) Just the sound of your voice...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And for her mother's sake she begins to read it... with no particular interest, like reading to someone a selection from a menu's choices...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dated "April 4, 1985." It says, "New Orleans." (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This is my last will and testament... (which starts to engage her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have much to leave... few possessions, no money really... I will go out of this world the same way I came in, alone and with nothing. (finding herself engaged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I have is my story... I'm writing it now while I still remember it..." She's interested. She looks over at her mother.    But he mother's eyes are closed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My name is Benjamin..." And Caroline's voice becomes a young MAN'S voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Benjamin Button... and I was born under unusual circumstances."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war to end all wars had ended. We see the streets of New Orleans are filled with drunken, singing revelers... cars jamming the cobblestones, people kissing, shouting joyful... Another burst of fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told it was an especially good night to be born...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And we see in the fireworks' light, a young MAN in his early 30s, THOMAS BUTTON, running up to the gate of a fashionable town home. He nearly collides with a PRIEST who arrives there at the same time. Thomas runs past him, up the steps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He runs past a solemn Maid and up a long staircase... barging into the MASTER BEDROOM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... where we see a young Woman is lying on a bloody bed, frantically being administered to by a DOCTOR with the help of the small domestic staff... the PRIEST enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas, I'm afraid she's not going to survive... And the Priest bends to say last rites over the pretty young woman... and the maids, bringing bedsheets, futilely start to change her bloody linens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough...! All of you! They move out of the way... and Thomas kneels beside his wife... She's pale white, fear in her soft brown eyes... He takes her hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came as quickly as I could... I'm sorry I took so long, the streets are filled with people... As if to underscore it, fireworks go off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going to be alright, my dearest darling... I will not let anything happen to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me, Thomas... And she is interrupted by the sudden CRY OF A BABY.    Bu Thomas can't take his eyes from his dying wife...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me, he has a place... He doesn't understand... She looks up at him... holds his hand tight... then she slips away... The Doctor listening for her pulse... He covers her... it's quiet... the Priest's murmured incantations... the housemaids crying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gave her life for me... And for that I am forever grateful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas, still holding her hand, is unable to let go... When we hear again the BABY CRYING... The BABY'S CRY is not quite right... It is not an infant's cry for succor, or a natural cry to exercise its new lungs... It's a deep, haunting cry from some primal soul... They all turn, and the room stills... listening as The BABY continues its mournful WAIL. Only Thomas goes to answer... The Baby in a basket, swaddled in a thick blanket, its face covered with cloth... Thomas goes to lift it, to see his son's face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Button...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the cloth anyway... He recoils... for he has seen some kind of horror... He makes the smallest of sounds, a whispered "Ohhhh." And then he suddenly snatches up the swaddled baby -- running with it out of the room... downstairs... outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Thomas, tears on his face, carrying his CRYING BABY, through the streets... Pushing through crowds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he comes along an old bridge over a waterway... the air heavy with the haze of fireworks... the water dark... brokenhearted, he lifts the baby to throw it into the black water... He is just at the apex of this throw when, despite his sadness, he can't bring himself to do it... Instead, cradles the newborn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I'm so sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LANTERN lights his face... A POLICEMAN down the way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing there!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BABY starts to CRY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas takes off... the Policeman after him... Thomas, carrying the CRYING BABY, running...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas, scuttling with the crying infant through narrow streets past the back porches and the back stairs of the large old moldering antebellum houses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to an old three-story house with a screened porch, VOICES from inside... PEOPLE TALKING and LAUGHING... The Baby, soothed by the soft yellow light, by the music of the voices, by the house itself -- stops its mournful cry. Thomas stops, catching his breath... He looks in through the back porch... the sounds of VOICES coming... Thomas quietly sets the baby on the back porch steps. He takes out every last dollar he has, tucking the money inside the Baby's blanket... We can just see the figures of two people coming from inside... Thomas knocks on the weathered screen door... And his decision made, he turns, moving away from the house, leaving his child behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could've sworn I heard somebody knockin'... When a young Black Woman, in a green dress, comes onto the porch... A thin, attractive woman, in her late 20s, with the sultry eyes of a lounge singer -- She's known as QUEENIE. She's followed by a handsome Black man, MR. WEATHERS -- that everyone calls TIZZY. She looks out the door, and not seeing anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not... She stands for a moment taking in the night air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air smells sweet... And she sings to herself... a song from the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look very handsome tonight, Ms. Queenie, handsome as I ever seen you... The green matches your eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fingering dress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't everyday a war's over, Mr. Weathers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to mark it somehow... You ain't no slouch yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, tips his hat... And they stand in the quiet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hambert's back in town... came home legless, but he home... we're gonna throw a party for him... help get himself situated... (beat) I know you was sweet on him one time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeter than I shoulda been... Lost his legs you say? "You never know what's comin' for you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if right on cue an older white Woman sticks her head out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Simone messed herself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got to stop doing that, or it's diapers for her... I'll be right there, Mrs. Jameson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman disappears inside.    Queenie, not anxious to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure is nice out here, Mr. Weathers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful nice, Ms. Queenie... Come out back for a moment... take your mind away from things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes open the porch screen door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Just a moment's time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers her his hand... She takes it... He backs out of the house, holding her hand, and he suddenly steps right on top of the Baby... The baby wails, Tizzy stumbles, nearly falls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in God's name...?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?     A fish crawl out of the river...? She moves to it... pushes aside the blanket, and freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God in heaven! IT IS THE VERY FIRST TIME WE HAVE SEEN THE BABY. What we see is the prominent bald head of any newborn... but it has the face, the wrinkled skin, the faded eyes, of an octogenarian. Indeed, if we didn't know any better, it would seem the newborn was a wrinkled decrepit sad-eyed old man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Goodness, the Lord did something here...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look like a milk wagon run over it... three times... and back... And they're both motionless, not quite sure what to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see it layin' there... I hope I didn't hurt it none... steppin' on it like that... The BABY won't stop its mournful cry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We best leave it to the police... I'll go -- Queenie hesitates... a longing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for sure nobody wanted to keep it... And making up her mind, she suddenly grabs up the crying baby, taking it inside... Tizzy, anxiously whispering something, going in after her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piano's playing a standard, people singing.... There's a myriad of old dark rooms... heavy furniture and carpets... an eclectic mixture of the possessions of those who have lived and died here over many years... and we see a parlor is crowded with Old People, from sixty to ninety-five, in various stages of health... various contraptions to keep them "afloat". An Old Age Home. We see Queenie moving quietly along a hallway, carrying the crying baby so as not to be seen. Tizzy, following her, still anxiously whispering after her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you, Queenie...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your water... (and to Tizzy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go see to them. He does what she asks. She hurries the baby into a small room, literally like a mouse house, under the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room tucked under the staircase...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie Apple... she went and messed herself all over again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Childress start her a bath... and mind your business, Mrs. Duprey... You'll be messing yourself soon enough too! There's a KNOCK on Queenie's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody stole my necklace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right with you, Mrs. Hollister... She whispers to The Baby, soothing it. And looking for a place to put it, she opens a dresser drawer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be as ugly as an old pot... but you still a child of God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie, Apple... she won't go take a bath wit'out you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercy, I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that she puts The Baby into the top dresser drawer... with her unmentionables... and shuts it... leaving it open just a crack, enough to breathe... Turning, she sees an Old Woman, looking very lost, looking in the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister gave those pearls to me... I can't find them anywhere... People are stealing my jewelry...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're right here, Mrs. Hollister, right 'round your pretty white neck... (moving her) Come on now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sound of a door chime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Rose has arrived for his visit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie takes a concerned look back at the Baby, and closes the door... And we stay behind for a moment... inside Queenie's underwear drawer, with the smell of a lilac sachet... is the Baby with the face of an old man... looking up at the sliver of light coming into the dresser drawer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Doctor, an older man in a tired suit, who has done this longer than he cares to remember, finishing examining one of the elderly boarders. He puts his things into his doctor's bag. Queenie comes beside him, saying something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baby is lying on Queenie's bed... Dr. Rose, stethoscope ever dangling, washes his hands in a sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He's nearly blind from cataracts... I'm not sure he can hear... His bones indicate severe arthritis... His skin has lost all elasticity... His hands and feet are ossified... He has all the deterioration, the infirmities, not of a newborn, but of a man well in his eighties on the way to his grave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to say he's dying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of old age. His body is failing him before his life's begun. They're still, looking at the strange baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did he come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my sister's child... From Lafayette. She had an unfortunate adventure. (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor child got the worse of it... came out white...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are places for 'unwanted' babies like these, Queenie... There's no room for another mouth to feed here... The Nolan Foundation, despite their good intentions, thinks this place is a large nuisance as it is... A baby here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appealing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said he don't have long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie -- some creatures aren't meant to survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the Baby, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a miracle, that's for certain... just not the kind of miracle one hopes to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old People are sitting around the parlor talking, playing cards... Queenie brings the baby bundle into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they stop what they are doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a visitor that will be staying with us for a little while... My sister had a child but couldn't see right by it... He's known as... (a hesitation naming him) Benjamin... (she likes the sound of it) Benjamin... He's not a well child... so we need to take very good care of him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tizzy's come out of the kitchen , watching with an air of strong disapproval... And an OLD WOMAN says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had ten children... there's not a baby I can't care for... let me see him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie hesitates, and gives the Baby to her... The Old Woman pushes the blanket back from the baby's face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) God in heaven, he looks just like my ex-husband...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's laughter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's prematurely old... Doctor Rose said he don't have much time on this earth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh. Their laughter makes the baby seem to smile... the lonely smile of an old, dying man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Queenie, unable to sleep, lying in bed, looking out a small window... there's a light KNOCK on the door... Tizzy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hambert sends his remembrance to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods... The baby cries out... and then it's quiet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning the baby) Are you right out of your mind? I know you don't got all the parts it takes to make one of your own... but this isn't yours to keep... this isn't even human kind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With nothing left to be said, he starts to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Mr. Weathers. Stay with me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slows.    She's quiet.     And she whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You never know what's comin' for you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as they move to be with one another, to make love; we look over at the dresser drawer -- open just a crack... Benjamin lying among the unmentionables, looking out at the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline with the "journal" on her knees. Daisy, eyes closed... the wind gathered in strength... furiously knocking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is any of this true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have such a lovely voice. Caroline shrugs.   She looks through the "book..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some pages seem to be torn out here... She discovers inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an old streetcar token. She gives it to her mother, folding her hand around it. But Daisy is somewhere else, looking out the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That clock... Just kept going, year after year after year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see "Mr. Cake's" clock with its cherubs pushing the "hands of progress," still marking time backwards... The year is now, "1925..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...I didn't know I was a child. I thought I was like everyone else who lived there, an old man, in my "golden years." The boarders eating dinner. Queenie, in a white uniform... along with Tizzy, wearing a chef's hat and apron, helping her serve. We move across the ancient faces... until we come to one particular face... Wearing eyeglasses now... but the same wrinkled face we've come to know... the face of a very old man...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The face of Benjamin Button, when he should normally be a six-year-old. He's sitting in a wheelchair now... small, shrunken, hunched with age, legs and hands crippled with arthritis... Eyeglasses are just one addition... a hearing aid... a bulky apparatus of its time, is in one ear... But if we look even closer we can see there are sprouts of hair... wisps of white... what would be the last hair for some... seem to be growing in... As we watch him eat, he uses his fork like a child might, banging it just for the hell of it making noise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop bangin' that fork... (fixing it in his arthritic hand) It's for eating, not for playin' with... And use your napkin, please Mr. Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he does as he's told... A staff member helps one of the old men, feeding him... Benjamin just another old man having dinner with his contemporaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of old people in rockers. Benjamin, like any six- year-old, bored, wheels his chair back and forth, between them... until one of the oldsters, who has had enough, sticks his cane in the spokes of his wheelchair, making him come to an abrupt stop... Benjamin, sitting with the other oldsters on the porch... the old people rocking... Sounds drift from the street beyond the wall... children playing... people talking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody says anything, rocking. Benjamin, eternally curious needing to know, suddenly wheels himself precariously to the very edge of the porch where the wall is lower and he just sees the street... children running on the street, playing... carriages dropping people off for a party... He leans forward to get an even better view... When Queenie suddenly grabs him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin! That's dangerous... Come back here...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Rolling his wheelchair away from the edge to the safety of the old people... out of sight of the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small room with the small window. We see Benjamin in a bed made on the floor... Queenie in her bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved her very much. She was my mother. And he reaches to hold her hand. She generously takes his hand... And they lay like that holding hands, Queenie in bed, her "son", the "old man" on the floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somedays I feel like I'm different from the day before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody feels different about themselves one way or another. We're all goin' the same way, just taking different roads to get there... You're on your own road, Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer do I have to live, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be thankful you got what you're given. You already here longer than you supposed to be. We see the door quietly open, Tizzy coming in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some nights, I would have to sleep alone. He looks at Benjamin, his signal to pick him up, carrying him out of the room, sitting him in his wheelchair, Tizzy going back down into the room to be with Queenie... shutting the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Old Woman's fallen fast asleep in an easy chair, a book on her lap. Benjamin sitting alone in his wheelchair, listening to the sounds of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mind. I would listen to the house breathing. All the people sleeping. I felt safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be he still wants to know "What's over there?" He wheels himself over to sit at the window looking outside... looking at the streetlights, the world beyond the gate... trying to see what's dangerous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a place of great routine... Every morning at 5:30, no matter the weather... General Winslow, U.S. Army Retired... raised the flag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see the very elderly General Winslow, doing just that... raising the flag in a downpour, only... he's naked. And as Queenie comes running across the lawn with a coat for him. There's the sound of SOMEONE SINGING OPERA...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Sybil Wagner, once a noted opera singer... well, she'd sing, Wagner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a Victrola playing, Mrs. Wagner in her nightgown at a window singing with the musical accompaniment at the top of her lungs... while, down the hall we see Queenie giving Benjamin a bath... massaging his poor crippled legs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna put some life into these old sticks for you... get you walkin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast was served promptly at six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin in his wheelchair, under Tizzy's tutelage, learning to cook... and simultaneously, to read...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we doin'?    What's that say there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biscuits... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think. That's a 'v' not a 'b.' Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you talkin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some staff come in getting platters of food...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many parts butter we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many parts flour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is four and two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tizzy smacks the back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a regular addin' machine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner was served promptly at six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tizzy washing dishes...Benjamin working with him... putting away cans... reading from one of the labels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomato, brown sugar, salt, myasses... Tizzy swats at him with his dish towel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Molasses"... And while washing the dishes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I learned to read when I was five. My grandfather was a dresser for a famous actor. He'd bring home every play for me to read. (Shakespeare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Kind keepers of my weak decaying age, Let dying Mortimer here rest himself. Even like a man new haled from the rack. So fare my limbs with long imprisonment. And these gray locks, the pursuivants of death, Nestor-like aged in an age of care, Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer." Benjamin's mouth agape, awed, taken by him, his majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought I was plain ignorant, didn't you? Benjamin never thought about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actor my grandfather worked for was John Wilkes Booth. He killed Abraham Lincoln. You never know... An old man looks in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's dessert...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it's served. Now sit your wrinkly butt back down, Mr. Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Saturday nights I would go to Queenie's church...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sweltering shout 'em up Negro gospel tent. Queenie pushes Benjamin in his wheelchair past a line of people looking to be healed, bringing him face to face with a mountain of a PREACHER, pouring sweat and full of fire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Queenie whispers something to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her parts are all twisted up inside so she can't have little children...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hand on her stomach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, if you could see clear to forgive this woman her sins so she can bear the fruit of the womb. (and shouts) Out damnable affliction!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses on her stomach... making Queenie nearly fall over... held up by a "NURSE" in a crisp white uniform. And once she's regained her balance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Benjamin) And what's this old man's irrediction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the devil on his back... trying to ride him into the grave before his time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches Benjamin) Out, Zebuchar! Out, Beelzebub! (after a beat) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And he says what is only true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seven, but I look a lot older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) God bless you.    He's seven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congregation laughs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a man who has optimism in his heart! Belief in his soul! We are all children in the eyes of God. Now we are going to get you out of that chair... we're gonna have you walk... (his hands on Ben's shoulders) In the name of God's glory, rise up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Benjamin, doing what he's asked, barely able to, his legs akimbo, stands... The people all applaud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now God is going to see you the rest of the way... He's going to see this little old man walk without the use of a crutch or a cane...! He's going walk by himself on faith and divine inspiration alone...! We'll show that Devil where to go...! Walk on...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Benjamin takes two very precarious steps and his poor arthritic legs give out... and he sprawls to the floor... The Aides in white nurse's uniforms move to help, but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch him! (kneeling to Benjamin) Rise up, old man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Benjamin stays crumpled on the floor... The Preacher comes to his feet, standing like a mountain over him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise up like Lazarus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin still lies on the floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said rise up!! And Benjamin, slowly but surely, makes his way to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and say hallelujah! (Hallelujah!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now walk, my old friend... Walk on...! And Benjamin, one crippled leg at a time, hobbles across the stage... The people urging him on... a string of "Hallelujahs...!" Queenie comes to join him... urging him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the Lord carry you... ... ...The Preacher, walking along with him, more a dance than a walk, shouting the name of the Lord... Queenie and The Preacher walking Benjamin across the stage... Benjamin making it to the other end... to a roar of "Amens"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, when I look back on it, it was kind of miraculous... But you know the saying, "...the Lord Giveth and the Lord Taketh away..." ... That mountain of a Preacher... in full exaltation to God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise be to the Lord on the highest...! Suddenly pitches over, flat on his face... Having had a spontaneous coronary... lying center-stage, deader than the proverbial doornail... The crisp uniformed "nurses" running to attend to him, and poor "old" Benjamin haplessly looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are gathered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were birthdays...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A lit cake is being brought in celebrating General Winslow's birthday. He stares at the cake, unhappily gets up, mutters something... and leaves. The oldsters eye the cake, and without a moment's hesitation, dig in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And mortality was a common visitor to our house... People came and went... Death was so frequent, I was never afraid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wagner's window open... and not a sound coming out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could hear when someone left us... there was a silence in the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small funeral at   an old cemetery... And while "DIE VALKYRIE" PLAYS on   her crank VICTROLA, an old man bangs cymbals as a grand   finale to the music... while we see SYBIL WAGNER, laid   to rest to sing in another choir:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin with his wondrous ancient face sitting in his wheelchair with the old people on the porch... watching the sun go down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a wonderful place to grow up. I was with people who had put away all the inconsequences of life, left in a state of purely being...wondering about the weather...the temperature of a bath...the light at the end of the day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And one of them, as if to underscore the point, farts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For everyone that died, someone would come to take their place... And we see Benjamin coming into the kitchen... Tizzy busy preparing lunch... Benjamin stops, seeing a tiny African man, his back to us, surrounded by old people standing on the lawn... He hears him telling them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My first wife and I are captured by neighbor tribe, cannibals... The old people shrink at the mention...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I escaped across the river...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wide eyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You escaped cannibals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife, she can't swim, so she eaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (telling Benjamin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Mr. Oti... He's an acquaintance of an acquaintance of mine...he'll be stayin' with us in the staff quarters for awhile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (telling old people)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Second wife stepped on viper and dies... (jocular) It was bad luck to be married to Mr. Oti. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am captured with six others by Baschiele tribe. They sell us to a big white man... He instinctively turns and sees Benjamin standing in the window watching him. When Mr. Oti spots him he quickly moves out of the window out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin lying on the floor by the stairs playing with some metal army men... when Mr. Oti's distinctive laugh, his voice, drifts up from under the stairs... Benjamin, getting his canes, goes to look... Mr. Oti, standing under the stairs in an alcove with some of the help, telling them his life story... but it's a completely different tone... a mockery of white people and their insanity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big White Man brings us to St. Louis, where they make our village at the 1904 World's Fair... They have us livin' in these little huts like we're livin' in Africa... people behind bars staring at us... we told not to look at them... to just go about our normal lives... what the hell they talkin' about... ? They all laugh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At night we're done bein' "savages..." we go over the wall into The Rosebud... we drank and laughed until the sun come up... and then we savages again... They nod enjoying the idea... And as Mr. Oti senses Benjamin's presence, turning... Benjamin retreating on his canes as fast as he can back up the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin sitting at the dining room table reading an oversized book of "Imaginary Beings..." He senses a presence... and Mr. Oti sits down across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you not so old as you looking. You just foolin' everybody. What happen, you get Madjembe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a madjembe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. This is just how I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Oti looks out at the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to get a cold root beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an echo) It's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up ready to go. Benjamin hesitates. He can see Queenie busy leaning out a window banging dust from a rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (last chance) ...Come on little man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite knowing the consequences he takes up his canes and follows Ngunda outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come outside. Children on the street playing. Seeing Benjamin, they come to a dead stop... staring at the freak from the old people's home, with another freak... Mr. Oti suddenly runs into the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin tries as best he can to keep up... Mr. Oti darts directly in front of a street car, waving his arms, making it come to an abrupt stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Another white man come to my country and say he want to talk to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move along the aisle of a streetcar... the various people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I am in the monkey house at "Philadelphia Zoological Park." Three thousand people show up my first day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and Ngunda siting in the back of the streetcar behind a moveable metal bar that has "Coloreds" painted on it... Mr. Oti taking a slug from a flask... A group of school children nearby can't take their eyes off the two of them... Mr. Oti takes his wallet out, taking out a folded piece of newspaper, showing it to Benjamin... "Bushman shares cage with park apes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it like living in a cage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stinks. The monkeys, they do some tricks... I throw spear... I wrestle with Kowali, she is orangutan... They have me file my teeth like a cannibal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows him his teeth filed into points like a cannibal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm not playing with monkeys - - they want me to run to bars in my cage with teeth to scare little children...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he suddenly jumps up and does just that, charging with his teeth bared at the school children... They scream... Mr. Oti, taking his seat again, laughs with Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: INT., (OR)
dialogues.text: Benjamin, ecstatic, his head out the streetcar window, Mr. Oti holding onto the back of his breeches from falling... Benjamin feeling the wind and the city wash over him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and Mr. Oti sitting on a bench at the peristyle of a park. Benjamin takes his first slug of a coca cola, taking too big a hit, the coke pouring out of his nose... Mr. Oti gives him a handkerchief... after he's wiped himself up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you go back home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War between English and Dutch people had broken up kingdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leave zoo. Go here. Go there. Everything okay. But I alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were all alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see little man, plenty times you be alone. You different like us, it's gonna be that way. But I tell you a little secret I find out. We know we alone. Fat people, skinny people, tall people, white people... they just as alone as us... But they scared shitless... He smiles a knowing smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing wrong with being alone... no sir... He looks out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about the river I grew up on. It would be good to sit by my river again. He looks at his watch.   He suddenly gets up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Oti and Benjamin coming along the street, music pouring out... They reach a corner where a tall octoroon woman is waiting. She broadly smiles seeing Mr. Oti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's my little man. You ready, sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, pure Ngunda) Always ready. Always ready. (introduces) Filamena, Mr. Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (respectful of his age) It's a pleasure to meet you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Benjamin) You can find your own way home, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although he's not sure he can... he nods, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The St. Charles Avenue line to Napoleon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, his arm around Filamena's waist, the two of them laughing, walk off... Benjamin's left standing on the street corner... he looks around to get his bearings... he moves along Bourbon Street... A streetcar comes along, bell clanging, it rushes by him... he watches it go... Clasping his canes, determined, he starts walking... bent over, one cane after the other... making his way along the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin coming back to the gate... and we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where in God's name have you been?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see Queenie standing on the porch... She's worried sick... she sees his hands are bleeding from blisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie cleaning his hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to scare the Holy Hell out of me! I was so worried about you...you take my breath away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had been the best day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the "caregiver," Dorothy Baker, comes back in. feels Daisy's pulse, straightens her pillow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's her breathing... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) They're sayin' it's gonna reach us late in the day... I'm goin' to get my baby and take him to my sister's... they said there's nothin' to worry about here in the hospital...Nurses are right here if you need them...I'll see you in about an hour if that'll be okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's fine...please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. It's momentarily quiet, the wind knocking at the window... Daisy, ruminating...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there just company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy had to go home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Daisy's mind is elsewhere...gesturing for her to keep reading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline looks back at the book.       Daisy closes her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "On Sundays the families would come and visit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boarders on the lawn with their loved ones... And we see an OLD MAN, walking with the aid of a cane coming out of the house onto the lawn... And as he moves through the people we see it's Benjamin... He has a single cane, standing more upright now, a distinctive shock of white hair, eyebrows... A distinguished looking man in his seventies, or, in normal years, a growing twelve-year-old boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Thanksgiving 1930, I met the person who changed my life forever. A chauffeured car has stopped... A Man is standing in the road, looking at the house through the gates... And we realize it's THOMAS BUTTON... looking for a glimpse of his son... Benjamin instinctively turns, but it's too late, his father's back in the car, being driven away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, an older woman nearby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely)                                          * Why, good day Mrs. Fuller...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might I say you are looking strikingly youthful...a single cane, your back as straight as an arrow... what elixir have you been drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs...And there's a voice that cuts through the day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma, look at me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, and Grandma Fuller turn to see a little girl, no more than eight, standing on a picnic table top doing pirouettes, one after another, for an admiring group of old people...she full curtsies, bowing --the way dancers do head to chest... then raising her head, laughing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that was really something... Come on over here, you... This is my granddaughter Daisy... This is Mr... Benjamin, I'm afraid I don't rightly know your last name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin is just fine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never, the rest of my                 * life, forget those blue eyes...               * And with great dignity -                                *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to all)                         *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good people, Supper is soived.                *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The families, along with Ngunda and Filamena, are gathered in the dining room, their heads bowed in prayer. We see Daisy across from Benjamin... The prayer's finished, it's noisy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pray to Bembe... the creator of all living things... she retired after all that work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (needing to top that)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know turkeys aren't really birds...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the pheasant family. They can hardly fly. It's sad don't you think? A bird, that can't fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like birds that can't fly. They're easy to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something to tell you all...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They're quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While we're giving thanks for God's blessings... I've had a miracle happen. (she touches her stomach) The Lord saw fit to answer my prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people applaud the good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she mean "answered her prayers?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to have a baby, silly. That's what my mother said when I was going to have a little brother. He didn't live long though. He didn't breathe right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we can see Benjamin's heart beginning to break... he looks over, Tizzy, proudly smiling... And as Queenie accepts congratulations... Benjamin's old wrinkled face, watching her... looks like he's going to cry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an ABSTRACT BLACK AND WHITE DRAWING.       And we a woman's voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the picture of Old Man Kangaroo at five in the afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN OLD FINGER comes in pointing to a drawing. We see Benjamin and Daisy, sitting close together on a sofa, and Daisy's grandmother, arm encircling them, is reading to them from Rudyard Kipling's "Just So Stories."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell it's late, because of the shadow here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and Daisy sitting rapt while she finishes reading to them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the time Old Man Kangaroo got                * his beautiful hind legs just as...                * I hope I'm saying this right...                   * just as Big God Ngog had promised.                * You can see that it's five                        * o'clock, because Big God Ngog's                   * pet tame clock says so.                           * (finishing) Isn't that something?                 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Daisy and Benjamin, thrilled, say: "Again. Read it again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, once more... but                         * afterwards (forgetting Benjamin's                 * age) both of you must promise to                  * go to bed...                                      *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both "I promise..." And as she starts to read all over again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin asleep in bed with one of the Old Men, MR. DAWS. The door opens. And Daisy, in her nightgown, has come inside... she slightly touches Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping? He shakes "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... She moves quickly out of the room and Benjamin gets up, and with the aid of his cane, follows her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old house still. Daisy, moving quietly down the stairs. Benjamin, his cane softly thumping the steps, following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going? She doesn't say anything. She leads him into the DINING ROOM... where we see the wash has been draped, sheets and pillowcases, like ghosts over the dining room table, and a smaller side table, and a buffet...to dry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under here... And she ducks under a sheet, beneath the dining table... Benjamin follows her into the "fort..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows about this but us.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They sit... The little girl, and the old man with the maturity of a ten year old boy, enjoying their secret lair... She takes a candle out of the folds of her nightgown... She tries to light it, but doesn't really know how to use matches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you light it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to use matches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be chicken...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite his caution, he lights the candle... the candlelight making it feel more secret...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a secret then you tell me one... (whispers) I saw mommy kissing another man. Her face was red from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm younger than I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) You don't seem like an old person... like my grandma... Are you sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) I heard Tizzy and my mother whisper. They said I was going to die soon. (smiles) But I fooled them so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy looks at him in the flickering candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are different than anybody I have ever met. Can I?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She innocently reaches to touch the skin on his cheek to see what it feels like... When suddenly a sheet is pulled back and Daisy's grandmother is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing under there? Who's idea was this candle? She angrily blows it out... and... to Daisy... taking her by the arm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's after midnight, you come right out here and get back up to bed...! (and for Benjamin, but saying it to Daisy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not to be playing together! Play with people your own age...! (moving her along)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you come back to bed, young lady...! You're too young to be wandering around in the night by yourself... (and a last word to Benjamin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed of yourself! And they're gone... Benjamin left sitting along under the sheets. There's a slight sound and he sees Queenie, in her nightgown, standing in the doorway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a different child... a man child. People aren't going to understand how different you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forlorn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with me, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God hasn't said yet. Now, back to bed and behave yourself. He crosses up the back stairs with the aid of his cane, and Mr. Oti, like a spectre, is sitting on one end of the back steps smoking a cigarette, drinking form his flask. He looks at Benjamin as he goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get used to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get back in that bed or I'll cane your old ass! Benjamin turns down the hallway and slips into the bedroom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin climbing back into bed with the Old Man. Turning his back to the old man. And Mr. Daws, unable to sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you I've been struck by lightning seven times. Once, when I was fixing a leak on the roof. And we see just that, the old man on a roof getting blasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once, when I was crossing the road to get the mail... And we see that, the man peacefully crossing a country road to get the mail, getting hit by lightning... But Benjamin just lays there looking out the window... all he can think about... despite everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forgot her blue eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words linger. Daisy, her extraordinary blue eyes, lying on her death bed... the rattle of the window in the wind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Mother? She nods "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man. He loved you from the first time he saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without complaint) Nobody has ever loved me that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impelling her) Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crossed out something... and then he's written... "When..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...When the baby came things were different..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin in his pajamas, quietly coming into the kitchen for something to eat... And he slows, seeing Queenie, taking a moment to herself, sitting at the kitchen table, peacefully breast-feeding her infant... as Benjamin slips back out unseen, closing the door after him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin lying on a small bed in the ATTIC... cluttered with years of accumulated things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I moved into my own room in the attic... I realized, despite a house filled with people that I loved, I was alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a noise. And we see Ngunda Oti is at the door, a suitcase in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come to say goodbye. I'm going away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going away?   Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't figure that out yet. I will send you a postcard when I get to there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your friend?   The tall lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not friends anymore. That's what happens with tall people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's gone.   Benjamin gets up going to the window. He looks outside. He can see Mr. Oti come onto the porch. There's a full moon. And as he walks off, his arrogant little walk, suitcase in hand, going out the gate, Benjamin watches him disappear into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent a lot of time by myself that year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin sitting at a table, an old man to look at but no more than twelve, busy playing with magnets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a refined, genteel OLD WOMAN, wearing a hat and gloves, a suitcase at her feet, flanked by an old DOG, just inside the front door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm moving in today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just then Queenie appears, the baby on her hip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome... we was expecting you... (to Benjamin) Could you show her upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will be staying in Mrs. Rousseau's old room. I'll be right with you with some fresh towels... (frowning) We don't usually let dogs in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's as old as the hills. Blind too. Can hardly get around, he won't be a bother much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, like any young boy, immediately pets the old dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess as long as he stays out from underfoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin helps her with her bags showing her up the stairs...the old dog dutifully following them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman starts to tell him her name... but we don't hear it because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) As hard as I try, I can't remember her name. Mrs. Lawson, or Mrs. Hartford, or maybe it was Maple? It's funny how sometimes the people we remember the least, make the greatest impression on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin sits petting the dog while the Woman puts her things away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember she wore diamonds... and she always dressed in fine clothing as if she was going out. Although, she never did and nobody would ever come to visit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Woman dressed nicely, sitting in a chair reading a book. She takes a look out the window at the families on the lawn and bends back to her book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She taught me how to play the piano...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman sitting with Benjamin teaching him how to play piano...playing a classical piece like Chopin...Benjamin trying his hand...sounding pretty bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't how well you play, it's how you feel about what you're playing. (whispers) Try this. And she plays a ragtime piece...New Orleans music...music for the other whole part of the soul... Benjamin tries his hand and actually plays it fairly well

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot help but put your entire self into the music. And he plays along with her...a piece he won't soon forget...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were many changes going on, some you could see... some you couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin taking a bath. An he notices a single gray hair floating on the surface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hair, had started growing, in all sorts of places... And he sees some hair is under his arms... and as he looks downward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along with other things...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Benjamin, naked, looking at himself in a mirror... like a young teenage boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt like I could do anything, that I could sprout wings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he flexes his muscles, feeling like a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's started to rain, the wind blowing, splattering rain against the window. Knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, darlin', the pain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get the nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries out of the room. Daisy looks out the window. The maelstrom of wind and rain. Caroline comes back with a Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not feeling too good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She adjusts the morphine drip.      Daisy lays back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody seems to know whether to stay or leave. The roads are filled from New Orleans to Baton Rouge already. I think I'm gonna ride it out. (finishing with the drip) There, that should make things easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy starts to feel the effects of the drip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Caroline) Have you had a chance to say your goodbyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline nods.    The Nurse nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father waited four hours for my brother to get here from Boger City. He couldn't go without him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She affectionately touches Daisy's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems like a sweet woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't spent as much time as I would have like with her the last few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another NURSE looks in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse quickly   goes out of the room. Caroline sits back down looking   at her mother...Daisy opens her eyes. they look at each   other... Caroline knowing Daisy wants to hear the sound   of her voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking up the book) The next page says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy shuts her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Queenie would let me go with Mr. Daws to Bridge City..To watch the boats go up and down the river...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The busy docks... Men waiting, hoping to find work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were hard times... people were doing anything they could to find work... And we see Benjamin, with Mr. Daws, "the lightning man," sitting on a bench with a line of other old men, "killing time," watching the boats going up and down the River...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you I was struck by lightning seven times? Once, when I was in a field tending to my cows. And we see just that, Mr. Daws, along with a cow of his, being hit by lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fourt' hand didn't show up... Anybody want to make $2 for a day's work around here... Benjamin turns... And he sees a man in his late 40s with his three man crew, standing on the deck of a TUGBOAT, and old rusted tug built out of charcoal iron... The man, its Captain MIKE... Has a thick Irish accent... For some reason none of the able-bodied men needing work respond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, nobody wants to get their hands dirty...! Nobody wants to do an honest days work for an honest day's pay...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never pays... He always says he'll have to owe it to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are all you afraid of workin' for a livin'? Somebody got to want a job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin suddenly springs up at the opportunity, waving his arms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got your sea legs old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling his legs) I do. I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good enough for me! Get your ass on board, we'll sure as hell find out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Benjamin gets on the boat, heading out to sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see Benjamin "learning the ropes..." Helping to tow the freighters, into and out of the River ports... Benjamin in this element, like a boy, his hair blowing, thrilled to be on the boat, thrilled by the adventure... willing to do anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was as happy as I could be... I would do anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needs a volunteah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning) Scrape off this bird shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away, sir...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he hops to it... Happily scraping off the bird shit... Happy to be doing anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I actually was going to be paid for something I would have done for free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put you on the books... pay you next time around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name was Captain Mike Clark... He'd been on boats since he was seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike's a hard drinker, God's last angry man... He's drinking as they go in for the night... Benjamin sitting with him in the wheelhouse... Capt. Mike jawing away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What were you born to do, old timer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't found out yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
