dialogues.text: You haven't found out yet?! How old are you, Benjamin, seventy somethin' or other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as old as I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Tha's a good one..." You older than Hades you creaky old bastard! What the hell you been doing with your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a short story...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you still get it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't understand) I do every morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old pole? The hard'n?     Can you still get it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not so sure) I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you had a woman, you creaky old bastard...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't believe his ears) You been on this earth for more than seventy years and you never got any?! That's the saddest thing I ever heard in my life. Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, hell man, you comin' with me!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took me to meet some friends...

dialogues.speaker: INT. A CLUB, THE FRENCH QUARTER
dialogues.text: Music playing loud... We see Benjamin and Capt Mike at the bar... Mike, hammered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You din't say?     What did your father do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never met my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lucky bastard! All father's want to do is hold you down!.. Out on my father's boat, working da two-a-days... This littl' fat bastard, "tug Irish," what they calls them. They say the Irish the only one's stupid `nough to work a tug. Them and the Portuguese, as we all know how stupid them Portuguese is. I fin'ly get up the nerves and tell him... "I don't wanta spend da rest of my life on a goddamn tugboat...!" You know what I'm sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't want to spend the rest of your life on a tugboat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely, damn right! So you know what my father says? He says "Who the hell you think you are?" "What the hell you think you can do?" I tell him. "Well if you askin' -- I want to be a artist." He laughs. He says, "If God wanted you to be an artist he would made you one." "God wanted you to work a tugboat just like me, and that's what you goin' to do?" "Now, if I ever hear you mention art again, I'll throw you overboard!" Well, I went and I show him... I made myself an artist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he suddenly takes off his shirt, pulls down his pants... And we see he's covered, from head to toe, with "his artwork," and incredible array of tattoos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tattoos artist...! I puts every one on myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they look it, upside down sideways and backwards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to skin me alive to take my art away from me now! When I'm dead I'm going to send him my arm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let anyone tell you different! You got to do what you meant to do! And I happen to be a god-damned artist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stating the obvious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're a tugboat captain. Which stops Captain Mike in mid rant... And he has no answer for... His only response is to glare at Benjamin... A back door opens, a slinky woman coming in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mike, we're ready for you and your friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go old timer... Break your cherry... This one's on me... As they go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reconsidering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's you pay for today... Don't ever let anybody tell you Captain Mike didn't give a man what he deserved...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at change he was given)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was $2 for a day's work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "you can't put a price on education..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mike and Benjamin in a small parlor where girls, both black and white, are sitting around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a night to remember... Captain Mike knows just who he wants and moves off with her... Benjamin left standing, not knowing what to do... None of the women seem to anxious to be with the old man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives me the willies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not for me, no ways...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin Girl, maybe 19, of mixed ethnicity, decides to take a chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you tonight, Grandpa?

dialogues.speaker: INT. A ROOM, WHORE HOUSE, FRENCH QUARTER
dialogues.text: And we see Benjamin and the girl sitting on a bed... And as she undresses him... First things first... tossing him a wash cloth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean yourself up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know what she means.. Taking the wash cloth he goes over to the sink and does what he knows how to do, wash his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that any better?

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE ROOM, WHORE HOUSE, FRENCH QUARTER
dialogues.text: She's pushing him down, hiking up her skirt, all business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go... Time's a wastin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs on top of him... And instinct takes over... But Benjamin being just a boy... and this being the first time, his excitement gets the immediate best of him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopping up) Come by anytime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to leave... But Benjamin, who likes this an awful lot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks and sees, sure enough... She climbs back on...the results are virtually the same if a bit longer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hat's off to you old timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up to go...she's made it to the door... when Benjamin says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slows, turns to look... And sure enough... He's as ready as he's ever going to be... As she looks at him, a look bordering on amazement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, Dick Tracy or something? I've got to rest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's just what she's doing... trying to catch her breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in heaven) Again?

dialogues.speaker: INT. PARLOR, WHORE HOUSE, THE QUARTER
dialogues.text: And we see Benjamin, at the door, happily smiling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurting) No, thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, floating on air, hovering, never wants to leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be here tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every night, but Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's finally able to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure made me understand the value of earning a living... the things it can buy you..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin turns to leave... we hear footsteps... And we see a man, putting on a raincoat, coming downstairs from one of those other rooms... We see it's Benjamin's father... THOMAS BUTTON... Seeing Benjamin he slows... Benjamin, unaware of who he is, turns and goes out...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET, FRENCH QUARTER
dialogues.text: It's a rainy night. Benjamin, feeling like a million bucks, walks along the street, going home... A chauffeured car pulls alongside him, the window rolled down... And we see Thomas Button in the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awful wet out. Can I offer you a ride somewhere...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Thomas, Thomas Button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (saying the name to himself) Benjamin... Yes, Benjamin... It's a pleasure to know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to stop and have a drink, Benjamin?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR, FRENCH QUARTER
dialogues.text: A small old bar. Benjamin and his father sitting in the back... The waiter comes over, deferring to Benjamin's age...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will it be sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have whatever he's having.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Sazerac for both of us...with whiskey instead of brandy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't drink do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a night for firsts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to a whore house either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an... experience...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly is. (and honestly) I'm not very experienced about a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't a bad thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a first time for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True enough. I don't mean to be rude... but your hands seem awful bent... It must be quite painful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know what I have. I have some form of a disease. I have a lot of catching up to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas is quiet.    And for many things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guileless) No need to be. Nothing wrong with old age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother says we're all born with something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm adopted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas looks at him... They get their drinks... Tap glasses, and drink. Benjamin coughs at the taste... But forces it down... And as they laugh at his discomfort...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas and Benjamin deep in conversation... and both of them more than a few sheets to the wind... Benjamin, particularly overblown like any first time drunk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My wife passed away many years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurring) I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died in childbirth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's a moment when it seems like Thomas might tell him, but despite the alcohol he thinks better of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasts, sadly) To children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, toasts) To mothers and fathers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After some moments:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What line of work are you in, Mr. Button?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buttons. "Button's Buttons." There isn't a button we don't make. Our biggest competition is B.F. Goodrich and his infernal zippers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you gentlemen like another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more Benjamin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll let me pay for it, Mr. Button...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a little of his hard earned pay... proud of himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of work do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proud of himself) I'm a tugboat man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car's stopped outside the gate... Benjamin is drunkenly getting out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoyed talking to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoyed drinking with you... He starts to wobble inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin... Benjamin slows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind, if time to time, I stopped by to say hello...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a drunken wave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drunkenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely... Mr. Button... Benjamin turns inside. Thomas looks after him for a long moment... And then he drives away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin holding the railing for support starts up the stairs for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been!? And we see Queenie has been sitting in the front room... where she can see out the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I listened to some music.... I -- He doesn't mention the whore... But generically says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met some people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And right on cue Benjamin, wobbles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think mama... I'm going to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to finish the evening, he throws up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family's on the lawn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved the weekends when she would come and spend the night with her grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy, nine now, asleep in bed with Grandma Fuller... We see Benjamin quietly enter... He gently nudges Daisy awake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Do you want to see something?   We have to keep it secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy, always willing, always brave, gets up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Get dressed. I'll meet you behind the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he leaves the room as quickly as he came...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, in an old peacoat, holding another -- waits... Daisy comes out... as he stops the door from slamming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssh... (whispers) Can you swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do anything you can do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put this on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a heavy coat...she puts it on... It's two sizes too big for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to go fast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she follows him between the houses... the two of them going quickly down the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog. The first light of dawn. A full compliment of boats tied up for the night... They scamper along the dock... to the "Chelsea" ...Benjamin helps her climb aboard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes downstairs to find -- Captain Mike sprawled across his bunk -- in all his naked tattooed glory, an empty bottle on the floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he has mejembe. (shaking him) Captain Mike... could you take us out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mike opens one eye... sees them standing there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what day it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what dat mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means I was very drunk last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're drunk every night.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Captain Mike just squints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A close friend... I wanted to show her the River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to be joy-ridin' with civilians... I could lose my license. That notion stops him for about a nanosecond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing a bottle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you standin' there for!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tugboat making its way through the fog... Benjamin standing with Daisy on the prow... the wind in their faces... And suddenly out of the fog a HORN BLARES... As loud as anything they have ever heard... and moving out of the mist, horn still echoing, a huge ocean liner appears... With three other tugboats pushing it to sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She put in for repair... a wounded duck... She's flyin' now... Captain Mike joins the tugs at the liner's side... the tugs sounding horns of their own... a symphony of a kind... What interests Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it take to build something like that? Passengers line the railing... continuing their adventure... And what interests Daisy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine all the places they're going to see... Daisy, thrilled, waves to them -- the passengers along the rail, waving back... Benjamin stands by Daisy, their hair blowing in the salty air....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Benjamin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish we could go with them... As they watch the liner, like a foggy dream, sailing away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain and wind knocking at the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish we could have... (the morphine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say something, Mother? And there's a hint of anxiety in Caroline now... anxiety coupled with exhaustion... Daisy doesn't say anything. Caroline worriedly looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to be getting worse. Daisy doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hearing me, mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that... time just seeped out of me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody will come and mop it up and that will be the end... Caroline can only listen... She takes a deep breath, gathering her strength...And when her mother's settled again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go on reading? She murmurs, "Hmmm?" as if she didn't know Caroline had stopped. Caroline looks back down at the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Things were changing quickly."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1935 We see Benjamin's REFLECTION in a mirror... WE PULL BACK TO SEE we're in his friend's room...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Benjamin sitting in a straight back chair... getting a haircut... the dog at their feet... the VICTROLA, as usual, is working overtime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how it's possible, you seem to have more hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a   little arrogant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if   I was to tell you I wasn't getting   older -- I was getting younger   than everybody else... And she then says, taking the wind out of his sails...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd feel very sorry for you... to have to see everybody you love, die before you. He's quiet, he hadn't thought of that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be an awful responsibility...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had never thought about life or death that way before... He's still... And seeing he's upset, she says the most beautiful of things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin... We're meant to lose the people we love. How else would we know how important they are to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And one fall day... a familiar visitor came knocking on our door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin knocking on the Woman's door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to go for a walk? There's no response. He opens it, going inside... The Woman is sitting in a chair by the window, the dog at her feet, the familiar Victrola playing dance music... He comes around the chair. And he sees she's still... perfectly still... her soul moved on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an old New Orleans paupers' cemetery... Benjamin and the mourners, and because he can't remember her name, around an unmarked grave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had taught me how to play the piano. As Benjamin watches the woman go to her final rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she taught me what it meant to miss somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin taking some things out of a dresser drawer, packing a suitcase...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had gone to a whore house, I'd had my first drink, I had said goodbye to one friend and buried another... In 1937, when I was coming to end of the 17th year of my life, I packed by bag. We see him putting some final things into the suitcase, closing it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and said goodbye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin moving through the parlor, one by one, saying his good-byes to the old people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew, life being what it was, I would probably never see them again... The familiar faces... And as we watch him affectionately touch or talk to each of them... we can just see out a screen window DAISY, almost thirteen now, leaning against the side of the house... Out of sight... as if she didn't say goodbye, he wouldn't leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see TIZZY on the porch holding Benjamin's suitcase for him... The woman's old dog lying beside him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, son. And we see Queenie has come out onto the porch with her little girl... and he holds Queenie... tears running down her face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mother... He bends to pet the old dog goodbye... He takes up his suitcase and starts off the porch... going down the walkway... he hesitates, and opens the gate... moving out onto the street... When suddenly Daisy is calling him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin... Benjamin... She comes running.   He stops to let her catch up to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To sea.    I'll send you a postcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From everywhere. Write me a postcard from everywhere... And with so much she wants to say, she can't say anything. So she runs away... He watches her go, watchers her thin legs running back down the street... and he turns and moves off along the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I went off to sea... We see him in the distance, the "old man", a 17 year old, suitcase in hand, going to find out who he is and what he is to become...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy's quiet.   Caroline can't avoid the howling of the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) I think I should find out what's going on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops her) There's a box of them... in a velvet bag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline, not sure what she wants, opens a red velvet bag... she finds a wooden cigar box...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what you're looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you wanted this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives her the box... Daisy, opens it... It's filled with postcards... Daisy, going through them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine... He sent me postcards from everywhere he went... every place he worked... Newfoundland... Baffin Bay... Liverpool... Glasgow...Narvik...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes one out, reading it... Taking up some others... looking... reading where they came from... reading off like an adventure... Daisy, the postcards, fond memories spread out on the bed around her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please keep reading, sugar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline takes another look at the window, then takes up the book...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting back down) "I had gone.."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... With Captain Mike's crew on the "Chelsea"..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tugboat, in the distance, steaming through the ocean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mike had contracted for three years with Moran Brothers Tug and Salvage... The old ship had been refitted with a diesel engine, and a new sea winch... We went around Florida and up the Atlantic seaboard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The refitted "Chelsea" on the Atlantic Ocean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were a crew of seven now... Captain Mike and me... the Cookie... Prentiss Mayes from Wilmington, Delaware... And we see an old sea hand in his domain, his GALLEY, smoking and coughing as he cooks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The Brody twins... Rick and Vic... Two burly hard working IDENTICAL TWIN BROTHERS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who got along fine at sea... but for some reason, once they were on dry land... couldn't stand the sight of each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers getting off the tug... and no sooner have they hit dry land they immediately get into a fist fight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was John Grimm, who fit his name... from Belvedere, South Dakota...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a dour looking man... who always expects the worst...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know one in every eight boats never returns, all hands lost at sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Pleasant Curtis who never said a word to anyone... except to himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The asocial Pleasant... talking to himself as he works...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin standing on the bow of the old tug as it sloughs through a fog on the high seas... ready to see the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy lying in bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote him constantly... told him everything I was doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tug on its way in for the night... Benjamin, sitting on a cleat, reading her letter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I told him they had invited me to New York to audition for the School of American Ballet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilting from the grey sky, onto an old landmark building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large open DANCE LOFT. And we see Daisy, dancing for a selection committee seated on metal chairs...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Daisy moving with technical proficiency -- but it's bloodless, without any real distinction... She gets nods - but no kudos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the "corps"... another dancing gypsy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Daisy training... just another lithe body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy in bed... Picking up another postcard, she stops, reading, slowing at a painful memory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Then he wrote me... "I've met somebody... and I've fallen in love..."

dialogues.speaker: INT. LANDMARK BUILDING, DANCE LOFT, NEW YORK, NIGHT
dialogues.text: And we see Daisy, sitting on the dance floor reading the very same POSTCARD, brokenhearted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Places everybody... Once again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troupe moves into their places...Daisy still just part of the crowd... The music starts... Now as Daisy dances... it is filled with pathos and lost love...and everyone takes notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy reading the very postcard some sixty odd years later... as if reading it for the first time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...I've met somebody...and I've fallen in love..." My, that was over... (and realizing) ...sixty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's quiet, looking out the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you love him, mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can a girl know about love?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she watches the rain on the window, Caroline takes it as her cue to keep reading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "...We were working in Murmansk, Russia..."

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Daisy stares at the window, the constant beating rain, the water running down the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmansk is on the Barrent Sea, the only ice-free ocean port in the Soviet Union...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see "Chelsea" working with other tugs as snow falls in the crowded Russian Harbor. They tow a large freighter into port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin... Benjamin, who is coiling rope on the bow, stands and looks at the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting down at him, wanting to know)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me how's it happen you showed up you were no bigger than a bollard. Now either I drink a helluva lot more than I think I do, or you sprouted... What's your secret? And Benjamin, tired of explanations, and what comes first to mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Captain, you do drink a lot... And that makes perfect sense to Mike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a drink, saluting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn right I do! And Benjamin stands on the bow... ready to see the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stayed at a small hotel with the grand name, "The Winter Palace."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow covers the street outside of a turn-of-the Century hotel... a front window looks into its lobby... "The Winter Palace Hotel."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a packed BAR off the lobby... We see Benjamin sitting with Captain Mike, their crew, and a mixture of other seamen, Russians and other ethnics, all speaking different languages, sitting and standing around tables cluttered with bottles and glasses... Captain Mike, drunk, his shirt off, is telling a Russian sailor, another interpreting for him -- about a tattoo he has over his heart... an upside down hummingbird...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saws this tattoo puts on a man's back in Singapore by Sakumoro, the greatest tattoo artist ever lived. I puts it on myself from mem'ry. And now we know why it's upside down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This idn't just anoter bird! Its heart rate's twelve hunerd beats a minute...! Its wings beats eighty times a second...! If you was to stop their wings from beatin, they would be dyin' in less than ten seconds...This is no ordinary bird, this is a frikkin' miracle! They slowed down the wings

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wit' movin' pictures, you know what it showed, they wing tips are doin' dis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he draws on a napkin a FIGURE EIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does you know what the figure- eight is the mathematical symbol of...?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pointing at the symbol...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Infinity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for some drunken reason, no matter what language they might speak, they all laugh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody, no matter what differences they had, the languages, the color of their skin, had one thing in common... they were drunk every single night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there's a shout -- and as if to underscore things, the Brody twins are kicking the shit out of each other again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin waiting for the small caged elevator to take him to his room. He gets in, the elevator operator about to shut the grill door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you wait, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see a WOMAN in her late 40s... getting on the elevator... Benjamin looks over at her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name was Elizabeth Abbott. She was not beautiful. She was plain as paper... But she was as pretty as any picture to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Plain as paper," ELIZABETH ABBOTT... Directly behind her walks a tall, tired man, in his 50s... By the look of his ruddy face, and her silent mien... they're both drunk... Benjamin finds himself looking at her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a distinctly English accent. Benjamin doesn't say a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you must know, we have a long standing agreement never to go to bed sober. Isn't that right darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband was Walter Abbott...He was Chief Minister of the British Trade Mission in Murmansk... and he was a spy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride up. Elizabeth has her shoes off...She sees him noting her stocking feet... The elevator finally rattles to a stop, and George and Elizabeth get off... Starting down the hall...she abruptly turns to say to Benjamin... so that it's completely understood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I broke the heel off of one of my shoes...I don't usually walk around in my bare feet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he watches her saunter along the hallway... the way drunks do... endeavoring to keep her dignity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were long days there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin on the tug, but it's less fun now, not much adventure, just hard work... Fighting the snow and the wind, they tow a large freighter into port...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, in his small room, cold air blasting through the windows, looking out the window into the snowy night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And longer nights... He lays on his bed looking out at the dark sky... the snow falling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One particular night... when I was having trouble sleeping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin trudges down the stairs, stepping tentatively into the empty lobby... He slows, seeing ELIZABETH ABBOTT in her bathrobe, sitting, alone and lonely... and it's not the first time for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I can't sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's quiet... She finally looks up... but doesn't say anything... There's an awkward moment...exacerbated by the stillness of the hotel in the middle of the night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to make some tea...would you like some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head no... He crosses through the empty bar, into an old KITCHEN... He looks for tea... Puts water in a kettle... As he watches the kettle boil... Elizabeth, her arms folded across her chest as if she were chilled, stands by the door... Benjamin, without asking, takes a cup for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk...? Honey...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some honey, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds a large honey jar... and seeing some dead flies in with the sweet syrup he asks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like flies with your tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles...for the first time... A thin smile... He starts to stir the tea... Elizabeth stopping him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must let it steep for a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit. There's a proper way to make tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where I'm from, they just want it to be hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't smile. He gives her a cup of tea... She cradles the cup... They're quiet, drinking their tea...two strangers... After some moments...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a seaman? I don't mean to be rude...but aren't you rather old to be working on a boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no age limit... as long as you can do the work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods... They're quiet again. She sits at an old wood counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have trouble sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an invitation to sit with her... He pulls a stool over sitting across from her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know I did... I usually sleep like a baby. Something kept me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never sleep... Well, rarely anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father, when he was in his eighties, was so sure he was going to die in his sleep... He would only take naps during the afternoon... so that death couldn't catch him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Die in his sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died sitting in his favorite chair listening to his favorite program on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have known something. She smiles at the idea... Another one... that goes as quickly as it's come... And it's quiet again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband's the British Trade Minister. We've been here fourteen months... We were supposed to be going to Peking... but it just never did work out. It never does seem to work out. Have you been to the Far East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't really been anywhere. I mean outside different harbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Orleans, Louisiana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pure Elizabeth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know there was another one. Which escapes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to America. Everywhere else. But not America. Am I missing anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply, guileless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mississippi River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she told me all the places she had been, and what she had seen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you what bars look like in places all over the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we talked until just before the dawn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first hint of daylight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the tea... She leaves as quietly as she entered... Benjamin remains standing for a moment...then shuts the light off behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And we went back to our rooms... to our separate lives... And as he goes back up the quiet stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every night... we would meet in the middle Of the night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin padding downstairs... slowing... happy to see Elizabeth, in her bathrobe, sitting in the empty lobby, waiting for him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Benjamin quietly talking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hotel in the middle of the night can be a magical place... And we see the empty front desk and tiny silver bell... The vacant lobby, with its musty old rugs... The open elevator, waiting... The dining room, with its crisp white tablecloths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mouse stopping and running and stopping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mouse crossing the lobby floor doing just that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radiator hissing. A sink dripping. A floor creaking. A curtain blowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see and hear it all... All the little sounds, a symphony, that make up life in a hotel in the middle of the night... Benjamin and Elizabeth sitting quietly drinking their tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something peaceful, even comforting, knowing that people you love are asleep in their beds, where nothing can harm them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie and Tizzy asleep together in her bed... Their child on the floor... The old people in their beds in the old house. Ngunda Oti asleep in a room somewhere. The unnamed woman's grave. A different kind of sleep. And of course Daisy, in a New York apartment loft with other dancers... sleeping peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and I would talk through the night until just before dawn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daylight starts to creep in... she gets up, about to go... she slows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may have given you the wrong impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrong impression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think I don't love my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married women don't usually sit with strange men in a hotel in the middle of the night. I certainly don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honestly) I don't know what married women do or don't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get one thing straight. I love him very much. I happen to think he is one of the smartest and most considerate men I ever met. It is not his fault I decided to spend my life in his shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that she gets up and leaves... Benjamin, left with that thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and Elizabeth in the empty dining room at a table with a white tablecloth... with some wine and cheese... She's laughing now, measurably loosened up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He started to take his pants off... I'm afraid he misread me completely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs. She looks through her wine glass at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you notice how people look better through a wine glass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds his up.... looking at her....She moves her glass just looking at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good looking man with or without a wine glass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks at the tablecloth with her finger next to his... She puts her finger over his making a cross...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all just crossing in the night. Sometimes we intersect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves her finger there for a moment... lingering... She abruptly moves it away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go to bed... he'll be up soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates... And she kisses him, and then hurries out of the dining room... As Benjamin sits in the empty dining room... the kiss left on his lips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the first time a woman had ever kissed me. It's something you never forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind and rain knocking at the window. Daisy silently lying in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you upset, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't say anything. Caroline, seeing her feet have come out of the covers, caring, fixes her blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some socks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to stop reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy's answer for her is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must have been very cold. I'm glad he had somebody to keep him warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Caroline takes as her cue to read on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat, reading) "I couldn't wait to see her again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin comes hurrying down the stairs. Elizabeth is waiting, as she normally is, but this time she is dressed... Lipstick and hair done... wearing a fur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) I'm not dressed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're delicious just as you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs, taking his arm, walking to the dining room as if going to dinner... They sit at a table... which she has set for them... Caviar and Vodka...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother with the cheese or the wine here, they're quite common... but the caviar and the vodka are plentiful and sublime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feeds him a spoonful of the caviar...Unaccustomed to it, he swallows it too quickly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time... If you eat it all at once there will be nothing left to enjoy... savor it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him another spoonful... and takes one herself... He takes his time... They both do... savoring it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring) Now, a swallow of vodka...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which they do... She laughs... Looking at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been with many women have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not many. At least none on a Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I feel like I'm with a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not far off... And it's a lovely thought... and it makes her think of her youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was nineteen, I tried to become the first woman to swim the English Channel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see just that....Young Elizabeth, in goggles, her body covered with grease, swimming with two escort boats across the English Channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The current was so strong...that for every stroke I took... I was pushed two strokes back... And we see just that, Elizabeth fighting the current...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swam for 32 hours... I was only two miles from the French shore... Elizabeth in sight of the lights of Calais...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it started to rain... And it starts to rain on her... Harder and harder... the shore is suddenly gone from sight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I couldn't go any further, and I just stopped... And we see her being taken onto a boat, a blanket wrapped around her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They asked me whether I would try again...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't I? She smiles, a young girl, full of life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did. As a matter of fact, I have never done much of anything with my life after that... And it's quiet. She touches his rough hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hands are very rough... you have grease under your nails... She runs her fingernail along his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can feel the wind on your face... They look at each other. And this time, Benjamin kisses her. It lingers... She stops herself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's the witching hour... She quickly gets up... And she's gone. As Benjamin sits in the empty dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took me a long time to go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Elizabeth nicely dressed, a bottle of champagne in her hand, sitting anxiously waiting. The elevator doors open. Benjamin in a suit and tie, as handsome as we've seen him steps out. She stands, takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look okay? I borrowed it from one of the men. It's his church suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take my breath away. She walks with him, champagne bottle in hand, through the empty lobby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing about clothing is, it should make you feel comfortable, then you will be comfortable... Come, let's take a walk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their arms in each other's, their breath showing in the night, they walk through the sleeping Russian town, their shadows in the moonlight. They stop to share a drink from the champagne bottle. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel so much younger when I'm with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it seems he's about to go on... But Elizabeth, flattered, takes it metaphorically...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's such a nice thing to say. You make me feel years younger, too. I wish I was. I would change so many things. I would undo all of my mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mistakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kept waiting, thinking I would do something to change my circumstance... Do something... But I never did... It's an awful waste, you can never get it back... wasted time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're quiet.    She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) If we're going to have an affair, you're never to look at me during the day, we must always part by sunrise, and we can never say "I love you..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's quiet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when it is over I will send you a card that will simply say goodbye... Those are the rules...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in the cold. His answer is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you as cold as I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) My god, colder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop to finish what's left of the champagne, Elizabeth hurling the bottle. The bottle falling silently into some fresh snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't even break a bottle here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other and they kiss. And without anything else needing to be said, they start back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin goes behind the registration desk, taking an empty room key off a hook... They cross to the elevator...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in the elevator as it ascends. Anticipating what's to come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move along a dark hallway. He quietly unlocks an empty room door... And as he follows her into the room... the door closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was the first woman who ever loved me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, in his peacoat, and stocking cap, snow on him, hurries into the hotel from work... He runs to the elevator, the doors just closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens. He goes inside.      And Elizabeth's husband is standing in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They silently ride up, not a word exchanged. The elevator stops. Elizabeth's husband gets out. As he quietly walks down the hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw each other every night... we always used the same room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the key going into the door... Benjamin and Elizabeth going inside closing the door behind them... leaving us with the quiet hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But each time seemed new and different...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see them as dawn creeps along the hallway, Benjamin and Elizabeth, leaving the room, not wanting to part, passionately kissing, and as they start to go their separate ways...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Elizabeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) You should swim the English channel again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as she laughs to herself and hurries off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until one night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin coming down the stairs, into the lobby to meet Elizabeth. And he slows...Elizabeth isn't there. He looks into the bar...the kitchen....the dining room... He goes back to the lobby, sitting on a lone sofa, waiting for her... A mouse runs across the marble floor, stops, looks at him and runs off... And he sits and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow shrouds the windows. We see Benjamin has fallen asleep on the sofa... There's the distinctive BELLOW of Captain Mike's VOICE. Benjamin wakes... He follows the bellowing to find Captain Mike with the tugboat CREW in the bar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roosevelt says we all got to do our part! After them Japs attacked Pearl Harbor everyone's got to! The Chelsea's been commissioned to serve in the United States Navy, to repair, tow, salvage and rescue... Anybody don't want to go to war, now's the time to say so... Once you set foot on that boat again, you're in the Navy friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go captain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy old timer. (to the men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hold it against no man. But speak up now or forever hold your water. And the Cook, Prentis Mayes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was planning on talking to you Cap'n Mike... My wife's doing poorly. I'd like to see her one more time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're free to get home any way you can Mr. Mayes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And the cook walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (always dour) Who do you intend to have cook then? One of the leading causes of death at sea is food poisoning, right after inadequate safety equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up cooking, sir. I'll take the job, if I'm not too old to serve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a real Johnny on the Spot, Benjamin. I'll take any able bodied mens who wants kick shit out of the Japs and the Huns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with no one dissenting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that's it! We's goin' to war, gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And filled with fervor, they give a cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin unlocking the door to his room. An ENVELOPE has been left under the door, he opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had left a note. She wrote, "it was nice to have met you." That was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he stands holding the letter in his room at the small Russian hotel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, I went to war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men on the tug on a dark gray sea....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't the war we expected. We would tow crippled ships... scraps of metal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: across the high seas... If there was a war, we didn't see it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what seemed exciting, the idea of war... is tedious... The "Chelsea" towing a strange hulking shape on the dark, empty sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a man assigned with us... The Chief Gunner loved the Navy, and most of all, he loved America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no other country in the world...! When YOU spell America, A.M.E.R.I.C.A. You're spelling freedom...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the young Gunnery Mate, no more than nineteen... sitting at his post on a high caliber machine gun... ready to kick some enemy ass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name was Dennis Smith and he was a full blooded Cherokee... His family had been in America for over five hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have these pacifists. They say they won't fight on conscience. Where would we be if everybody decided to act according to their conscience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out his Window) Keeps it down, would you chief!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back inside... And as they settle into their tasks..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his gun, to himself, the last word) Where else can you shoot white people and get away with it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin's the only one around to hear him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worked in the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin busy preparing a meal in the galley kitchen. The Perpetually silent Pleasant Curtis, on kitchen duty, helping him with the preparation... while they work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make conversation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from the Kentucky mountains aren't you? It must be pretty there.. Pleasant Curtis doesn't say a word. Benjamin shrugging, puts the pie in an oven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men; including Dennis Smith, Pleasant Curtis, John Grimm, the "fighting" Brody twins, Benjamin serving them, silently eating dinner, rolling with endless rolling Ocean. Pleasant, not interested, just gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something not normal about him. As they silently eat, mostly bored...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking outside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever said "War is hell," doesn't know shit from shinola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see "Chelsea," a steel tow line splayed out from its winch, towing a large crippled freighter across the ocean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were towing a British freighter, that had gone dead in the water, 800 miles to Halifax for repair... We see Benjamin and the crew watching the ship on the tow line run out some thousand feet behind them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin awake in his bunk, Dennis Smith asleep in the bunk above him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pleasant Curtis seemingly asleep in his bunk below him... Benjamin looking out at the black sea... and out of the silence Pleasant Curtis for the first time speaks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been watching you. You seem trustworthy. If something happens to me... could you see this gets to my wife...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Benjamin a folded up handkerchief...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had given me all of his pay... he hadn't spent a dime of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything happens I want my family to know I was thinking about them, and if I could have, I'd have come back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that said he turns back over... And as Benjamin looks at the dark foreboding sea... suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) All hands on deck!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bolt from their bunks... Going outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mike stands by the wheelhouse... silently looking at the ocean... They see bodies of men, dead men, floating by them... One and two at first... then three and four... and then more and more until they are moving through a carpet of bodies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war found us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they move through the water... their propeller literally chopping up bodies, to where they have to veritably shut their engines down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A transport carrying 900 men had been hit by a torpedo. We were first to arrive at the scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as the tug arrives at the scene we see a TRANSPORT VESSEL, with a gaping hole in its midships sinking quickly... Fuel oil burning on the water...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It's then we see the true horror of the men in the water... in the burning black oil... The transport boat silently slips into the water, disappearing under the sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tug moves through the thick black smoke... Benjamin and the other crewmen watching along the rails...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't a sound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the   lapping of water, and the tugboat's engines, there   isn't... just the silence of death... Something else   appears, doming onto the surface like a spectre... the   U-BOAT that had reeked this havoc... looking to see   the results... Captain Mike sees the sub...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mad as hell) We can't run from the fucker and we can't hide...! There's only one thing we can do...! (and he shouts) Battle Stations...!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run to their battle stations...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mike at the wheel in the pilot house, turning the tug, furiously bearing down on the surfaced submarine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A German submariner, on the conning tower, seeing the Tugboat, turns the .50 caliber machine gun on the tugboat... Benjamin is grazed by a bullet, his forehead cut open, bleeding... Despite the strafing the tug is relentless... The submarine, seeing it is about to be rammed tries to dive... but it's too late... the tugboat ramming the submarine... severing the U-Boat in half. The concussion of the collision has triggered a torpedo in the sinking submarine's torpedo shaft, the torpedo exploding, bursting the submarine, and in the process, blasting away under the stern of the tugboat... the men on the stern blown to pieces... Benjamin's literally thrown against the wheel house... He manages to get to his feet, the tug listing, beginning to sink... There's a man's voice...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And he sees, Captain Mike riddled with bullets, his body covered with blood... Benjamin bends to him... Captain Mike trembling as he lays dying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at what they did! They shot holes in me! They shots the hell out my paintin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His body, his tattoos, like a ripped canvas, is riddled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen a lot of things. Tell me it's going to be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to heaven Captain Mike. You're going to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin sits beside him, his friend Captain Mike, dying. And a light comes in Captain Mike's eyes... an understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be mad as a mad dawg at the way things wents... You can swear, curse the fates, regret every'ting you ever dids... but when it comes to the end... You have to lets go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks in Benjamin's old eyes....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a hand, old man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he holds Benjamin's hand ready to meet his maker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two destroyers and a hospital ship in the battle zone flow... Planes circling... The water still speckled with debris, and bodies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin at the railing of a Liberty Ship.. He watches the "Chelsea" sink, disappearing under the sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 736 men died that day... I said my goodbyes to the Cherokee, Dennis Smith, John Grimm who was right, he was going to die there... I sent Pleasant Curtis' wife his money... I said goodbye to the twin, Vic Brody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He instinctively turns, and sees Rick Brody looking out a porthole, lost without his twin brother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to Mike Clark... Captain of the tugboat "Chelsea."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A storage cabinet is opened, a sailor taking out a wreath, from a supply of just such wreaths...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sailor shrugs, giving him the wreath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said goodbye to all the other men... who had dreams of their own... All the men who wanted to be plumbers or singers or insurance salesmen or doctors... or lawyers or Indian chiefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly, angrily, he throws the wreath into the water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out here, death didn't seem normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin standing at the rail of the ship... no longer a boy... And a SAILOR standing beside him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This don't get fixed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin's quiet. When suddenly a HUMMINGBIRD comes flying across the water... It circles the wreath, the way Hummingbirds do... and then flies off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd never seen a hummingbird that far out to sea before...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And as Benjamin stands at the railing, looking at the sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the spring of 1945.... when I was 26 years old... I went home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin, suitcase in hand, going up the walk to the old house. We're struck by the difference... the old man who had left to see the world has returned a strikingly handsome man in his fifties. The old blind dog, smelling ham, ambles off the porch to meet him. Nothing seems to have changed. An old woman we don't know is rocking on the porch. A black girl, just 14... is hanging out wash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your mother home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gettin' supper ready.... He goes up the porch, inside....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some old folks are in the front room... Nobody we know... He moves by them into the kitchen... the stovetop smoking and gurgling... He goes into the dining room... Queenie is busy setting the table... He watches her for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenie... She turns, seeing him... she drops a plate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord have mercy....you're home... She runs to embrace him... We see she's aged... the eight years he's been gone... and the 25 years or so since we've known her... now in her fifties...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (asks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that mama? The Girl comes inside... curious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother, Benjamin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know he was my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) There's a shit load of things you don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But her interest is in Benjamin....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him) You look like you've been born again... you're younger than the springtime... I think that preacher laid the hands on you brought you a second life... I knew the moment I saw you -- you were special... Every night I got on my knees asking the Good Lord to bring you back safely. Remember what I told you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know what's comin' for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they both share a good laugh at her homily... glad to be together once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you learn anything worth repeating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches the scar, from the bullet, on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seen some pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some joy too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, that too. And she holds him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Tizzy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Weathers died in his sleep one night last April. He's sleeping comfortably now in the cemetery on St. James street, God rest his soul...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry... She turns from him so as not to cry....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one or two of them left now... They all just about new... waitin' their turn like everybody else... I am so glad to have I you back. Now we got to find you some proper work and get you married right... And as she goes about readying the table for dinner, humming to herself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin sitting with a row of oldsters. And feeling out of place, out of time, he gets up and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin playing the piano in the parlor, the particular tune the Woman had taught him... an old man sitting nearby, seemingly listening... Queenie, looking in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time... he's stone deaf... You'll be staying in what was Mrs. DeSeroux's room now, you're too much of a man to stay in the attic anymore. She goes about her business... And as Benjamin goes back to playing the piano for the deaf man... playing for himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mr. Daws, much older now, asleep in an easy chair.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Benjamin standing at the familiar window, listening to the silence of the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a funny thing about coming home. Smells the same. Looks the same. Feels the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Daws awakens.    Seeing Benjamin.   As if he never le

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you I've been struck by lightning seven times. Once I was sitting in my truck listening to the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see just that Mr. Daws sitting in his truck getting belted by lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize what's changed, is you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Benjamin stands locking out the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And one evening, not long after I had been back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Benjamin, coming down the stairs. He happens to glance out a casement window... He slows... He can just see part of a TAXI coming to stop at the gate. He moves to the next landing...where he can see a figure is getting out of the cab... The figure of a young woman, wearing a beret, a dark coat and lace up boots... She strides through the gate... It takes us a moment to recognize her... the leggy thirteen year old girl is gone... replaced by a confident woman in her early twenties... with her red hair and her blue eyes she could be no one else but DAISY. Benjamin follows her progress, moving through the parlor, watching her out the screened windows... She moves gracefully past the porch with its swings... The unnamed woman's old dog, smelling her, comes to greet her... Daisy going around to the back of the house... Benjamin moving to the back door, and just as Daisy starts to knock... Benjamin opening it... Momentarily startled, she doesn't recognize him.... and asks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, excuse me... is Queenie here...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy... it's me, Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hardly can believe her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin...Oh my God it's you... Of course it's you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace, and there's a moment when the touch is not just of old friends, but something different... and they both, in that moment recognize that things will never be the same... Daisy, over-hugging him... the way young people do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, how are you? It's been such a long time... There's so much I want to know... When did you come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few weeks ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to Queenie...she told me you were in the war...somewhere at sea... I was so worried about you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I had left she was a girl... and a woman had taken her place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get over you -- You are so lovely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stopped writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel terrible about it... (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that I see you I feel even worse... Look at you...Daisy Fuller...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy's still. She touches her old face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said, "The most beautiful," Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else did he say about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Everything, in that moment, had changed between us..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and Daisy going up the back stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get over you're home... I've been planning to come by for awhile... my grandmother, you remember Grandma Fuller... of course you remember her... she passed away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that... I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wanting to get some of her things... ...They go into her grandmother's room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her grandmother's things are in boxes neatly stacked in a corner, waiting to be taken away... Daisy starts to go through them... Benjamin gives her a hand... As they go through things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I open the door, and you're actually standing there...It must be fate... What do they call it, "Kismet"? I read a book about a man named Edgar Cayce, a psychic, everything is predetermined...I like to think it's fate. What do you think, Benjamin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how it works, but I'm sure glad it happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They inadvertently touch... the electricity of friction... both aware of the closeness... they move ever so slightly apart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
